image.altText: Woman and children gesture and cry at house hit by airstrikes.

items.synopsis: The first 20 trucks bearing aid since Israel began a siege of Gaza pass through Egypt's border crossing, as Israel's military says it plans to step up its attacks on the area.

title.children: First aid reaches besieged Gaza, as Israel says it plans to 'deepen' attacks before ground invasion

image.altText: A woman looks at the camera with a neutral expression

items.synopsis: Oria Rosenberger is an Israeli who wants peace and is planning to leave the country. But when her brother was sent to the frontlines, it put her in a delicate position.

title.children: Coming here is 'everyone's worst nightmare', but in Israel, it's where the biggest crowds are

image.altText: rapper J Emz smiles at director Gabriel Gasparinatos as they sit side by side in an interview room

items.synopsis: ONEFOUR rapper J Emz and director of the group's new documentary say they hope the film shows a new side to the popular group that has been mired in controversy and police attention.

title.children: Police at Sydney rappers' film premiere a case of life imitating art

image.altText: An illustration of an Indigenous flag at half mast on a gloomy evening

items.synopsis: Ask an Aboriginal person how they define reconciliation and the answers are not flags, morning teas and welcomes-to-country. Their answers are land rights, greater autonomy and treaties, writes Bridget Brennan.

title.children: Is reconciliation really dead?

image.altText: A young boy cries as he sits on a bed and is treated by a doctor in a hospital

items.synopsis: The United Nations hopes a second convoy of trucks will be sent into Gaza, where hospitals are "overwhelmed and lacking resources". Follow live.

title.children: Gaza's health system 'facing collapse', as UN negotiates for second aid convoy

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A top official with Hezbollah has vowed that Israel will pay a high price if it starts a ground offensive in the Gaza Strip, and he claims his militant group based in Lebanon is already "in the heart of the battle". The comments by Hezbollah's deputy leader, Sheikh Naim Kassem, came as Israel shelled and made drone strikes in southern Lebanon and Hezbollah fired rockets and missiles toward Israel, according to the Associated Press. Hezbollah says six of its fighters were killed on Saturday. It isn't yet possible to independently verify the claim. For Hezbollah, heating up the Lebanon-Israel border has a clear purpose, Kassem says: "We are trying to weaken the Israeli enemy and let them know that we are ready." There are concerns that Iran-backed Hezbollah, which is believed to have a large weapons arsenal, might try to open a new front in the Israel-Hamas war with a large-scale attack on northern Israel. AP
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Hezbollah official says his group is already 'in the heart' of Israel-Hamas war

props.alt: Smoke rises behind a large border wall, near an army base

children.content: Smoke rises from inside an Israeli army position which was allegedly hit by Hezbollah fighters on Friday.
(AP: Hassan Ammar)

A top official with Hezbollah has vowed that Israel will pay a high price if it starts a ground offensive in the Gaza Strip, and he claims his militant group based in Lebanon is already "in the heart of the battle".

The comments by Hezbollah's deputy leader, Sheikh Naim Kassem, came as Israel shelled and made drone strikes in southern Lebanon and Hezbollah fired rockets and missiles toward Israel, according to the Associated Press.
Hezbollah says six of its fighters were killed on Saturday. It isn't yet possible to independently verify the claim.
For Hezbollah, heating up the Lebanon-Israel border has a clear purpose, Kassem says:
"We are trying to weaken the Israeli enemy and let them know that we are ready."
There are concerns that Iran-backed Hezbollah, which is believed to have a large weapons arsenal, might try to open a new front in the Israel-Hamas war with a large-scale attack on northern Israel.
AP

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Israel says it plans to step up its attacks on the Gaza Strip as preparation for the next stage of its war on Hamas. Asked about a possible ground invasion into Gaza, an Israeli military representative told reporters on Saturday night that the military was trying to create optimal conditions beforehand. "We will deepen our attacks to minimise the dangers to our forces in the next stages of the war. We are going to increase the attacks, from today," they said. They also repeated calls for residents of Gaza City to head south for their safety. AP
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israel says it will increase attacks on Gaza

children.content: Israel says it plans to step up its attacks on the Gaza Strip as preparation for the next stage of its war on Hamas.
Asked about a possible ground invasion into Gaza, an Israeli military representative told reporters on Saturday night that the military was trying to create optimal conditions beforehand.
"We will deepen our attacks to minimise the dangers to our forces in the next stages of the war. We are going to increase the attacks, from today," they said.
They also repeated calls for residents of Gaza City to head south for their safety.
AP

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The United Nations is hoping a second convoy of trucks will be sent into Gaza on Sunday under a light inspection system that will allow relief deliveries to scale up into next week, its humanitarian chief says. A first convoy of 20 trucks arrived in Gaza through the Rafah crossing with Egypt on Saturday, but efforts to deliver supplies to the besieged enclave have been held up by Israeli demands to verify aid. "It's incredibly important that there is no gap in the aid going across the border," UN aid chief Martin Griffiths said. The UN says 100 trucks daily are needed to meet essential needs in Gaza, where Israel has imposed a "total siege". Israel says aid can enter through Egypt as long as supplies do not end up in the hands of Hamas. In a social media post on Sunday morning, UN Secretary-General António Guterres called for three things: Immediate, unrestricted & sustained humanitarian aid for civilians in Gaza Immediate & unconditional release of all hostages Immediate & dedicated efforts to prevent the spread of violence, which is increasing the risk of spillover
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: UN says it's negotiating a second convoy of aid trucks

props.alt: People watch and wave Palestinian flags as aid trucks pass through a border crossing

children.content: (Reuters)

The United Nations is hoping a second convoy of trucks will be sent into Gaza on Sunday under a light inspection system that will allow relief deliveries to scale up into next week, its humanitarian chief says.
A first convoy of 20 trucks arrived in Gaza
through the Rafah crossing with Egypt on Saturday, but efforts to deliver supplies to the besieged enclave have been held up by Israeli demands to verify aid.
"It's incredibly important that there is no gap in the aid going across the border," UN aid chief Martin Griffiths said.
The UN says 100 trucks daily are needed to meet essential needs in Gaza, where Israel has imposed a "total siege".
Israel says aid can enter through Egypt as long as supplies do not end up in the hands of Hamas.
In a social media post on Sunday morning, UN Secretary-General
António Guterres called for three things:
Immediate, unrestricted
sustained humanitarian aid for civilians in Gaza
Immediate
unconditional release of all hostages
Immediate
dedicated efforts to prevent the spread of violence, which is increasing the risk of spillover

image.altText: Whatsapp icon on a phone screen.

items.synopsis: The aged pensioner had an old couch she was wanting to get rid of, so she tried to sell it online. This simple decision resulted in the loss of faith in her bank — and saw more than $1,000 taken from her account.

title.children: Virginia's bank refunded her when she was scammed. Then the scammer produced a 'delivery confirmation'

image.altText: Headshot photo of Bill Hayden in 1962.

items.synopsis: Once described as the greatest man never to become prime minister, Bill Hayden surrendered a shot at the top job for the sake of Labor Party unity.

title.children: Bill Hayden, former governor-general and Labor luminary, dies aged 90

image.altText: SAF celebrate

items.synopsis: South Africa is through to the Rugby World Cup final, edging England in a thrilling contest at the Stade de France 16-15 to earn the right to take on New Zealand in next week's final.

title.children: 'It is what we stand for as a team and as a nation': Springboks win extraordinary Rugby World Cup semifinal against England

image.altText: ministers line up on the steps of government house, paul keating centre

items.synopsis: The Labor luminary, who brought in universal healthcare and the single mother's pension under the Whitlam government, has died aged 90.

title.children: 'The greatest man never to have become prime minister': Friends and former rivals pay tribute to Bill Hayden

image.altText: A man looks dejected while walking from a cricket field.

items.synopsis: England's Cricket World Cup title defence is all but over after a thumping at the hands of South Africa.

title.children: England tumbles to second last on World Cup table after demoralising loss to South Africa

image.altText: A screenshot showing a red and yellow circle where earthquakes occurred on Victoria's coast.

items.synopsis: A magnitude-5.0 earthquake recorded near Apollo Bay just after 2am is felt by thousands of Victorians, and as far away as Tasmania's King Island.

title.children: Great Ocean Road earthquake felt as far away as Bendigo and Tasmania

image.altText: fdheli_PalestineRally_2110_13-35-56.18

items.synopsis: Up to 15,000 people took part in Sydney's pro-Palestinian rally, according to NSW Police, as thousands more turn out in other Australian capital cities.

title.children: Colours of Palestinian flag take over streets in Sydney, Brisbane and Perth

image.altText: Alyce Wood and daughter Florence on a pier, holding a paddle, smiling.

items.synopsis: Dual Olympian Alyce Wood found managing her exercise during pregnancy challenging due to a lack of research on the topic. She's now returned to sport postpartum but rejects the idea of "bouncing back".

title.children: Confused about how much exercise to do while pregnant? Elite athletes are too

image.altText: A marble bust of Roman Emperor Marcus Aurelius

items.synopsis: Ancient philosopher Marcus Aurelius on online meetings, hot-desking and what to do if you send an email to a friend but accidentally reply-all to the whole company.

title.children: What would Marcus Aurelius make of people who have their camera off during online meetings?

image.altText: A woman wearing a blue denim jacket and red glasses.

items.synopsis: Landlords across Victoria say they are selling off their investment properties, citing issues such as rising costs and changing regulations as those pushing them away from housing.

title.children: Is it a bad time to be a property investor? These landlords think so, and they're selling up

image.altText: Iris Leeson sits with her baby on her lap, sitting next to husband, reading book to baby

items.synopsis: Ms Leeson said losing her mum was isolating and lonely, but now she's found a community of women who have been through significant loss and are finding ways to support one another.

title.children: Iris's mother died when she was 19. Now she's helping others experiencing grief

image.altText: People enjoying the beach at Noosa on a sunny day

items.synopsis: A report into spiralling rent prices has found some Sunshine Coast residents are spending up to 60 per cent of their income on rent, with social housing groups saying some locals are being forced out.

title.children: Tenants forced to consider leaving coastal towns as rent rises hit 'severe crisis' levels

image.altText: a woman with dark hair smiles directly at the camera leaning her chin on her hand

items.synopsis: For more than two decades, Penny kept up a facade of being fine — but she often felt like she was "going insane".

title.children: Why it can be problematic to say 'I'm a little bit OCD'

image.altText: A group of children play on a pile of rope at Kurisa village.

items.synopsis: The global transition to electric vehicles is driving rapid expansion of Indonesia's nickel industry — but do the benefits outweigh the costs?

title.children: How ordinary Indonesians are being affected by the global transition to electric vehicles

image.altText: Policeman in uniform with Victoria Police backdrop

items.synopsis: Victoria Police is warning action will be taken against anyone who uses the Nazi salute in public, now that the gesture has become illegal.

title.children: It is now illegal to use the Nazi salute in Victoria and police are warning they will take action if they see it

image.altText: Kids running in playground

items.synopsis: Most concussions don't happen on the sports field. Brain injury is a risk for everyone — and a single knock can have lasting consequences — but it is under recognised in the community and can be difficult to get support.

title.children: Ettie fell over playing 'monster, monster'. She's still feeling the impact of concussion 18 months later

image.altText: Politician Jim Jordan wearing blue suit stands with arms folded by himself amidst empty brown leather chairs

items.synopsis: Jim Jordan's quest to become speaker of the US House of Representatives ends as fellow Republicans revoke their support after a third failed vote.

title.children: Donald Trump-backed Jim Jordan's bid to become US speaker ends after embarrassing third defeat in vote

image.altText: A crowd of people, some wearing hi-vis vests, gather beside several trucks loaded with covered goods as they emerge from a wall.

items.synopsis: Israel allows trucks carrying food, water and medicine through the southern crossing from Egypt into Gaza, ahead of a potential invasion, the Associated Press reports.

title.children: Rafah crossing opens to allow trucks carrying humanitarian aid into Gaza — as it happened

image.altText: A fire burning a Hat Head taken from Crescent Head

items.synopsis: Residents across the state are being warned to brace for dangerous bushfire conditions this weekend, after a challenging week for many communities.

title.children: With winds blowing hot and cold, this weekend is risky on the bushfire front in NSW

image.altText: A man stands in a paddock, looking out across the landscape.

items.synopsis: Farmers have gathered in a dusty paddock in northern New South Wales to share how they have improved their readiness for life without regular rain.

title.children: Dry conditions are returning to northern NSW, but these farmers have learnt a thing or two about managing drought

image.altText: A nurse smiling in a hospital room.

items.synopsis: The brown brick hospital on the main drag into Bundaberg is an unassuming building, but many locals are still traumatised by what went on here when Jayant Patel, aka Dr Death, was director of surgery.

title.children: When patients started dying at a regional hospital, one nurse risked it all to blow the whistle

image.altText: A framed photograph of a man smiling

items.synopsis: Hundreds of people — family, friends, community leaders, and strangers — gather to pay tribute to those who were lost after a bus rolled at a roundabout near Greta in June.

title.children: ​​​​​​​Tributes flow for the 'beautiful ten' at memorial service for Hunter Valley wedding bus crash victims

image.altText: A police car parked on Old Dookie Road in Shepparton in front of a road closed sign.

items.synopsis: A five-year-old girl and an unborn baby have been killed in a multi-vehicle collision in northern Victoria, police have confirmed. Four adults were injured.

title.children: Unborn baby and five-year-old girl confirmed as victims of fatal crash near Shepparton

image.altText: A man poses in a shop window in Poland before allegedly stealing jewellery, food and clothing, according to police.

items.synopsis: Police say the man posed motionless until closing time, before robbing a jewellery stand in a Polish shopping centre.

image.altText: Zion Garcia

items.synopsis: The Texan festival has come to Australia for the first time and is thrusting young artists from Western Sydney into the spotlight.

title.children: Zion Garcia watched SXSW clips as a teenager. Now he's performed at the festival in Sydney

image.altText: A composite image of the Blythe Star and one of the survivors, Mick Doleman.

items.synopsis: It has been 50 years since the Blythe Star sank in Australia's unforgiving southern waters. Now, survivor Mick Doleman is telling the full story of how the crew lasted nearly two weeks in hostile seas, and helping give a voice to those who didn't return.

title.children: 10 desperate men, shipwrecked off the harsh Tasmanian coast and left for dead. How did anyone live to tell the tale?
